clinical_study.brief_title: Assessing the Effect of Periodontal Debridement, Tongue Cleaning and Mouth Rinsing for the Treatment of Oral Malodour

brief_summary.textblock: This study evaluates the short and long term effect of dental cleaning and mouthrinsing for the treatment of bad breath

detailed_description.textblock: The majority of bad breath producing bacteria can be found in pockets around the gums and the top of the tongue. It is generally agreed that one of the most effective means of controlling the production of bad breath gases from these bacteria is their mechanical removal. Tongue cleaning has shown consistent results in the reduction of bad breath, while dental cleaning has shown positive, but less conclusive results. The addition of a mouth rinse to mechanical measures has shown medium-term effectiveness, however there is currently no information available that describes the long-term impact of mechanical and chemical measures for the treatment of bad breath and the appropriate interval for follow-up and on-going management to prevent difficult cases.

primary_outcome.measure: Reduction of oral malodour below threshold

arm_group.description: Periodontal debridement, tongue cleaning, mouth rinsing with 20ml Cetylpyridium Chloride daily for 24 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Organoleptic score of 2 or more, and volatile sulfur compound score of greater than 1.5ng/10ml of hydrogen sulfide and 0.5ng/10ml of methyl mercaptan
Exclusion Criteria:
- Moderate to severe periodontal disease, systemic illness or dental disease associated with halitosis, antibiotic use in the past month, need for antibiotic prophylaxis for dental procedures and current smokers
